text:
I've found dockerising python development to be very liberating - i'm an oldschool desktop dev learning python/docker & bflw/api at the same time. Using azure not aws. don't want to turn this into a docker conversation but I found this guide useful - onlything not working for me is the watchmedo
<https://hackernoon.com/efficient-development-with-docker-and-docker-compose-e354b4d24831>

text: I take that to mean actual dev and not just deployments though ... unit tests obviously help but I'm still pretty keen on using a debugger ... and that's what holds me back from doing proper dev on containers (for Python at least. Eclipse has the notion of remote debuggers for Java).

elements.text: I take that to mean actual dev and not just deployments though ... unit tests obviously help but I'm still pretty keen on using a debugger ... and that's what holds me back from doing proper dev on containers (for Python at least. Eclipse has the notion of remote debuggers for Java).

text: I believe the paid version of PyCharm has remote debugging for Python but I don't feel like shelling out for that :grin:

elements.text: I believe the paid version of PyCharm has remote debugging for Python but I don't feel like shelling out for that

text: unless you are using a slim/alpine image or something funky I see no benefit in debugging your code in a container. Normally flow is code/debug in an ide -> create container -> run tests using unittest or docker-compose-test -> deploy

elements.text: unless you are using a slim/alpine image or something funky I see no benefit in debugging your code in a container. Normally flow is code/debug in an ide -> create container -> run tests using unittest or docker-compose-test -> deploy

text: <@UM3970H0T> has joined the channel

One cool thing for having a quicker development cycle without having to build docker images and push to your online enviroment is to proxy the traffic from the cluster to you local machine, then you do not have to setup docker-compose and can run against real environment and still being fast. Just run your app as usual with trafic routed to it or make db calls. Personally I use telepresence for kubernetes, but I expect there are others for similar environments.

elements.text: One cool thing for having a quicker development cycle without having to build docker images and push to your online enviroment is to proxy the traffic from the cluster to you local machine, then you do not have to setup docker-compose and can run against real environment and still being fast. Just run your app as usual with trafic routed to it or make db calls. Personally I use telepresence for kubernetes, but I expect there are others for similar environments.

text: it would be nice to have a single environment where you did everything, instead of maintaining the same packages/versions/etc between the local machine and container ... there's really a lot of overlap between venv and containers ... both create a separate environment for you to work in ... ideally you'd just use one ... i.e point your IDE at a container that has everything set up ... want to try a new version of Python, then point to a different container .. but of course. debugging with containers is difficult which is why I asked the original question

elements.text: it would be nice to have a single environment where you did everything, instead of maintaining the same packages/versions/etc between the local machine and container ... there's really a lot of overlap between venv and containers ... both create a separate environment for you to work in ... ideally you'd just use one ... i.e point your IDE at a container that has everything set up ... want to try a new version of Python, then point to a different container .. but of course. debugging with containers is difficult which is why I asked the original question

text: those were my original thoughts when I sat down to do our project using BFLW but I ended up in local mode + containers after dev was done :grin:
